questions.question: What were the two chief magistrates called in Carthage's government system?
options: Consuls, who were elected annually and rotated among different wealthy families equally
Suffets, who held executive authority but often came from same merchant families repeatedly
Praetors, who served under the primary magistrates and commanded military forces
Tribunes, who represented the interests of common people against aristocratic merchant families
Strategoi, who commanded both military and civilian administrative functions together

questions.question: How did Carthaginian political power differ from Roman political power in the 3rd century BCE?
options: Carthage had more democratic institutions while Rome remained under monarchical rule exclusively
Carthage had strong provincial governors throughout its empire while Rome lacked administrators
Rome relied on mercenary armies while Carthage used citizen-soldiers exclusively throughout territories
Rome distributed power broadly while Carthage concentrated power in wealthy merchant families

questions.question: What role did the popular assembly play in Carthaginian government and political decision-making?
options: It had limited power compared to the Senate and the governing suffets' authority
It held supreme authority and made all military and civilian policy decisions directly
It served only ceremonial functions and had no real influence on government policies
It commanded all military forces and could override decisions made by elected officials
It controlled the state treasury and allocated all resources to various governmental departments

questions.question: Which gods held primary religious significance in Carthaginian religion and society? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Baal Hammon, the sky god and chief deity in Carthaginian religious practice throughout territories
Tanit, the chief goddess worshipped alongside Baal Hammon as a primary religious figure
Astarte, the Phoenician love goddess whose worship was central to Carthaginian religious observance
Melqart, the Phoenician god of the city associated with Tyre but not widely worshipped in Carthage
Reshef, the Phoenician war god whose temples were constructed throughout Carthaginian territories

questions.question: What made Carthage's control of the tin trade particularly valuable economically?
options: Tin was essential for making bronze, a critical metal in the ancient world widely
Tin could be sold at extremely high prices throughout Mediterranean trading networks continuously
Tin came exclusively from Carthaginian territories and could not be obtained elsewhere ever
Tin was used to manufacture advanced weapons that made Carthage militarily superior always
Tin was required for all Carthaginian religious sacrifices and temple construction projects

questions.question: How did Carthage develop sophisticated financial instruments and banking practices early?
options: Carthage borrowed banking systems directly from Egyptian cities and adopted practices unchanged
Carthaginian financial practices were based on Roman accounting methods and administrative procedures
Carthage had no banking system and relied exclusively on direct barter trade exchanges only
Carthaginian merchants used contracts, letters of credit, and financial instruments for long-distance trade

questions.question: What types of soldiers did Carthage recruit for its mercenary armies? (SELECT ALL THAT APPLY)
options: Libyan infantry from North African territories under Carthaginian control and influence
Spanish warriors renowned for skill and ferocity using the curved falcata sword effectively
Numidian cavalry specialists considered among the best mounted warriors in the ancient world
Roman citizen-soldiers borrowed from Rome through formal military alliance agreements and treaties
Libyan cavalry providing additional mounted forces from North African regional territories

questions.question: What significant advantage did Carthage's mercenary system provide to its military operations?
options: Access to diverse military traditions and specialized troops from throughout the empire
Citizen-soldiers who were completely loyal to Carthage and could never be defeated militarily
Control of Mediterranean naval routes that prevented enemy fleet movements completely always
Unlimited military manpower that could be mobilized quickly without any logistical constraints whatsoever

questions.question: What major disadvantage accompanied Carthage's reliance on mercenary armies for military operations?
options: Mercenary soldiers refused to fight at sea and only participated in land warfare campaigns
Mercenary soldiers were less skilled than citizen-soldiers in traditional Mediterranean warfare tactics
Soldiers' loyalty depended on payment and armies couldn't be mobilized as quickly as citizen armies
Mercenary armies frequently rebelled against Carthaginian authority and established independent kingdoms

questions.question: How did Greek cultural influence affect Carthaginian civilization during the 4th-3rd centuries BCE?
options: Carthage completely rejected Greek culture and maintained purely Phoenician traditions exclusively
Greek merchants, architecture, and artistic styles influenced Carthaginian culture while maintaining identity
Carthage became politically dominated by Greek city-states and lost independence entirely permanently
Carthaginian elites adopted only Greek military tactics while rejecting all other cultural practices
